module.title: anthroponymic proper nouns
module.p: Anthroponymic proper nouns are proper nouns which are also anthroponyms, i.e. they name people (and other personified entities like toys, boats, pet animals &c).
Anthroponymic proper nouns are divided into two classes according to gender –

ol.li: Feminine anthroponymic proper nouns name female persons, e.g. Mairead Margaret, Caitrìona Catherine. They are slenderised, but not (necessarily) lenited, in both the dative and genitive cases, e.g. le Maireid with Margaret, taigh Maireid Margaret’s house.

Masculine anthroponymic (andronymic) proper nouns name male persons, e.g. Seumas James, Dòmhnall Donald. They are unchanged in the dative case, and are both slenderised and lenited in the genitive, e.g. le Seumas with James, taigh Sheumais James’ house.

module.p: Some anthroponymic proper nouns have diminutive variants, e.g. Seumaidh Jimmy and Peigi Peggy are diminutive versions of Seumas and Mairead respectively.

Two anthroponymic proper nouns may be juxtaposed in strict apposition (i.e. agreeing in both gender and case), e.g. Màiri Sìne Mary Jane, Dòmhnall Uilleam Donald William (cf. taigh Dhòmhnaill Uilleim Donald William’s house, not taigh Dhòmhnaill Uilleam).
Anthroponymic proper nouns may be modified by other words as follows –

ol.li: An anthroponymic proper noun may be modified by a following adjective, agreeing in both gender and case, e.g. Mairead Bhàn Fair Margaret, Seumas Mòr Big James.

An anthroponymic proper noun may be followed, in apposition, by a simple indefinite common noun denoting a trade, profession or calling, e.g. Dòmhnall breabadair Donald the weaver Mairead dhubh bhanarach Margaret the dark-headed milkmaid
Surnames

module.p: Anthroponymic proper nouns may be juxtaposed with, modified or specified by other words as follows –

ol.li: An anthroponymic proper noun may be specified by a following proper noun or definite common noun in the genitive case, e.g. Mairead Dhòmhnaill Donald’s Margaret, Iain Chanaidh John of Canna, Anna a’ Bhreabadair the weaver’s Anna.

An anthroponymic proper noun may be followed, in apposition, by a definite noun (common or proper), e.g. Alasdair an ceard-umha Alexander the coppersmith, Mairead nighean a’ Mhinisteir Margaret the Minister’s daughter, Seumas mac Dhòmhnaill James son of Donald

box.title: feminine anthroponymic proper nouns
box.p: Mairead and Sìne are examples of feminine anthroponymic proper nouns. They name female persons, and are slenderised, though not (necessarily) lenited, in both the dative and genitive cases –
Note that feminine anthroponymic proper nouns ending with a vowel or slender consonant show no change in the dative or genitive.
Note also that genitive forms of feminine anthroponymic proper nouns are systematically lenited in certain dialects, cf. taigh Mhaireid.

box.p: Dòmhnall and Murchadh are examples of masculine anthroponymic proper nouns. They name male persons, are unchanged in the dative case, and are both slenderised and lenited in the genitive –

ul.li: Mac dé a son of a god versus Mac Dhé the Son of God – dia (genitive dè) is a (masculine) common noun, which has been ‘namified’ into the masculine anthroponymic proper noun Dia (genitive Dhè).

Mac Dhòmhnuill the son of Donald versus Mac Dòmhnuill a son of a Donald – Dòmhnall (genitive Dhòmhnaill) is a masculine anthroponymic proper noun which has been ‘de-namified’ into the masculine common noun Dòmhnall (genitive Dòmhnaill), meaning a man called Donald.

box.title: diminutive anthroponymic proper nouns
box.p: Diminutive anthroponymic proper nouns are informal, colloquial variants of more official anthroponymic proper nouns.
These are declined for case in the same way as other anthroponymic proper nouns.

box.title: ‘double-barrelling’ of anthroponymic proper nouns
box.p: Two anthroponymic proper nouns may be combined in apposition to form a ‘double-barrelled’ personal name, e.g. Màiri Sìne Mary Jane, Dòmhnall Uilleam Donald William.
Since the two nouns are in strict apposition, they agree in both gender and case –
Note the following vocative examples from Cox (2017: 125) with regard to lenition of the second noun – A Thormoid Chaluim! A Mhàiri Sìne!

box.title: anthroponymic proper nouns modified by adjectives
box.p: An anthroponymic proper noun may be modified by one or more following adjectives, e.g. Mairead Bhàn Fair Margaret, Dòmhnall Beag Ruadh Little Red Donald.
The adjectives agree with the proper noun in both gender and case –
Note that the adjectives are capitalised depending on whether they are interpreted to be an intrinsic part of the person’s nickname or not.
[Common adjectives used: hair colour, size, &c]

box.title: anthroponymic proper nouns with nouns denoting trades
box.p: An anthroponymic proper noun may be followed, in apposition, by a simple indefinite common noun denoting a trade, profession or calling.
Since the two nouns are in apposition, they agree in case and number.
Note the following –

ol.li: A single adjective modifier can appear between the name and the noun, e.g. Mairead dhubh bhanarach Margaret the dark-headed milkmaid, Dòmhnall ruadh breabadair Donald the ginger weaver. However, more than one adjective is not allowed in this construction – Mairead bheag dhubh bhanarach (but cf. Mairead bheag dhubh a’ bhanarach Margaret the little dark-headed milkmaid).
A surname cannot intervene betwen the name and the noun in this construction, – Dòmhnall MacLeòid breabadair (but cf. Dòmhnall MacLeòid am breabadair Donald MacLeod the weaver).
A compound noun is not permitted in this construction, e.g. Alasdair fear lagha (but cf. Alasdair am fear lagha Alexander the lawyer).

box.p: [The question of lenition of the noun needs to be investigated here.]

ol.li: Dughall taillear Dugald (the) tailor – the definite article is not required because the noun is not a compound, and there is no intervening surname cf. Dughall an taillear, Alasdair an ceard-umha Alexander the copper-smith, Alasdair ceard-umha, Iain Caimbeul am maor John Campbell the sheriff-officer, Iain Caimbeul maor. The two nouns ‘are declined together as a compound Noun’, implying (I think) that the genitive should be (taigh) Dhughaill thailleir.

Eobhan ban ciobair fair Evan the shepherd – the definite article is not required because there is only one adjective cf. Eobhan ban an ciobair, Mòrag bheag bhoidheach a’ bhanarach pretty little Sarah the milkmaid, Mòrag bheag bhoidheach bhanarach.

Ceit ’bhanarach Kate the milkmaid – Gillies claims the definite article is ‘implied’ with a feminine noun, hence the lenition, but ‘is not written, nor spoken’ cf. Ceit a’ bhanarach. There is probably a better explanation for the lenition!
Eobhan cìobair Ewen the shepherd.
Ioseph saor John the Carpenter.
(beannachd) Chaluim ghobha Smith Malcom’s blessing.
Domhnull ruadh tàillear Red Donald the tailor.
miann Dhomhnuill amadain Fool Donald’s fancy.

box.title: anthroponymic proper nouns with specifiers
box.p: An anthroponymic proper noun may be specified by a following proper noun or definite common noun in the genitive case.
Some common patterns are as follows –

ol.li: The specifier is a proper anthroponymic noun denoting a parent (or grandparent), e.g. Mairead Dhòmhnaill Donald’s Mary.
The specifier is a proper toponymic noun denoting the place of origin or residence, e.g. Iain Chanaidh John of Canna.
The specifier is a definite common noun describing the job or profession of a parent (or grandparent), e.g. Dòmhnall a’ bhreabadair Donald of the weaver.

box.p: Note that adjectives can intervene between the proper noun and its specifier, e.g. Mairead Bhàn Dhòmhnaill Donald’s Fair Margaret, Iain Mòr a’ Mhinisteir Big John of the Minister.
Note also that genitive proper noun specifiers can be chained to form patronymics, e.g. Iain Dhòmhnaill Sheumais Dhonnchaidh John son of Donald son of James son of Duncan.

ol.li: Dughall an tailleir Donald of the tailor – ‘some immediate dependent or a son of the tailor’.

box.title: anthroponymic proper nouns with appositives

ol.li: Alasdair an ceard-umha Alexander the copper-smith – the definite article is necessary because of the compound noun, cf. Alasdair ceard-umha, Dughall taillear Dugald (the) tailor, Dughall an taillear, Ceit ’bhanarach Kate the milkmaid, Ceit a’ bhanarach.

Iain Caimbeul am maor John Campbell the sheriff-officer – the definite article is necessary because of the surname, cf. Iain Caimbeul maor, Iain maor John the sheriff-officer, Iain am maor. The stated genitive form is (tigh) Iain Chaimbeil am maor, rather than (tigh) Iain Chaimbeil a’ mhaoir.

Mòrag bheag bhoidheach a’ bhanarach pretty little Sarah the milkmaid – the definite article is necessary because of the second adjective, cf. Mòrag bheag bhoidheach bhanarach, Eobhan ban ciobair fair Evan the shepherd, Eobhan ban an ciobair.
Domhnall Camshron am maighstir-sgoil Donald Cameron the schoolmaster has the genitive (tigh) Dhomhnaill Chamshroin am maighstir-sgoil, rather than (tigh) Dhomhnaill Chamshroin a’ mhaighstir-sgoil.
(mac) Ioseiph an saor (the son) of Joseph-the-carpenter (never the carpenter son of Joseph) is the genitive of Ioseaph an saor, rather than (mac) Ioseiph an t-saoir.
(thuit e le laimh) Oscair an laoch cruadalach (he fell by the hand) of Oscar the bold hero is the genitive of Oscar an laoch cruadalach, rather than (thuit e le laimh) Oscair an laoich chruadalaich.
(do) a bhràithribh uile mic an righ (to) all his brothers the sons of the king is the dative of a bhràithrean uile mic an righ, rather than presumably (do) a bhràithribh uile macaibh an righ.

box.p: Gillies follows Stewart (1876) in noting that patronymics and Biblical Gaelic appear to be more conservative (arguably hypercorrect) in case usage –

ol.li: Donnchadh mac Chailein mhic Dhomhnuill Duncan the son of Colin the son of Donald, rather than Donnchadh mac Chailein m(h)ac Dhomhnuill.
do mhacaibh Bharsaili a’ Ghileadaich unto the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite (1 Kings 2:7), rather than do mhacaibh Bharsaili an Gileadach.
righ-chathair Dhaibhidh (a) athar the throne of his father David (1 Kings 2:12), rather than righ-chathair Dhaibhidh (a) athair.
do thaobh Bheniamin am brathar for their brother Benjamin (Judges 21:6), rather than do thaobh Bheniamin am brathair.

ag gabhail nan clar cloiche, eadhon chlar a’ cho-cheangail to receive the tablets of stone, even the tablets of the covenant (Deuteronymy 9:9), rather than ag gabhail nan clar cloiche, eadhon claran a’ cho-cheangal.
Alasdair, an ceard-umha Alexander the coppersmith.
Ailean, am muillear-luaidh Allan the fulling-miller.
Alasdair Tàillear, an clachair Alexander Taylor the mason.
Iain Caimbeul am maor John Campbell the Officer.
Eachainn glas òg, an tuathanach Young wan Hector, the farmer.
Mòrag bheag chiar, a’ bhanarach Little swarthy Sally, the Dairymaid.
Each Iain Chaimbeil, am maor the horse of John Campbell the Officer.
Tigh Sheumais, a mhac the house of James, his son.
air deas làimh Dhé an t-athair on the right hand of God the father cf. the hypercorrect air deas làimh Dhé an athar.

li.m: da bhràithribh uile, mic an rìgh
li.en: to all his brothers, the King’s sons (1 Kings 1 9)

ol.li: ri Sarai, a bhean to Sarah, his wife (Genesis 12 11).

ul.li: Mac Rìgh Seumas, Tearlach Stiubhart Charles Stuart, son of King James – cf. Mac Rìgh Sheumais. (also: p. 104)
Do theaghlach rìgh Fionghall to the family of King Fingal – cf. do theaghlach Rìgh Fhionghaill.
Sin as onoir Shir Seumas that is the honour of Sir James – cf. onoir Shir Sheumais.
ri linn ban-righ Màiri in Queen Mary’s reign.
leabhar an deadhain Seumas MacGrìogair cf. leabhar an deadhain Sheumais MhicGrìogair
ciad mhac a’ Phrionnsa Teàrlach cf. ciad mhac a’ Phrionnsa Theàrlaich
eaglais an Urramaich MacCoinnich cf. eaglais an Urramaich MhicCoinnich

module.p: Calder (1923: 104) – use of definite article with anthroponymic proper nouns to imply repute:
